<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 119, 378, 144]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSE™

CANDIDATE NAME

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[620, 220, 720, 250]]<|/det|>
CANDIDATE NUMBER  

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[735, 210, 905, 255]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 348, 293]]<|/det|>
## ADDITIONAL MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
0606/13  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 154, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
October/November 2022  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 326, 905, 341]]<|/det|>
2 hours  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 400]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 228, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 280, 450]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 450, 760, 466]]<|/det|>
Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 806, 482]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 482, 562, 497]]<|/det|>
Write your answer to each question in the space provided.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 498, 480, 512]]<|/det|>
Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 358, 527]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 528, 480, 543]]<|/det|>
You should use a calculator where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 543, 880, 573]]<|/det|>
You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 574, 860, 604]]<|/det|>
Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 634, 218, 649]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 651, 730, 682]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 80. The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[403, 79, 604, 97]]<|/det|>
Mathematical Formulae  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[443, 140, 566, 159]]<|/det|>
## 1. ALGEBRA  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 172, 245, 191]]<|/det|>
Quadratic Equation  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 202, 390, 221]]<|/det|>
For the equation \(ax^{2} + bx + c = 0\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[421, 220, 586, 256]]<|/det|>
\[x = \frac{-b\pm\sqrt{b^{2} - 4ac}}{2a}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 278, 233, 295]]<|/det|>
Binomial Theorem  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[250, 298, 757, 338]]<|/det|>
\[(a + b)^{n} = a^{n} + \binom{n}{1} a^{n - 1}b + \binom{n}{2} a^{n - 2}b^{2} + \ldots +\binom{n}{r} a^{n - r}b^{r} + \ldots +b^{n}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 351, 504, 390]]<|/det|>
where \(n\) is a positive integer and \(\binom{n}{r} = \frac{n!}{(n - r)!r!}\)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 416, 391, 435]]<|/det|>
Arithmetic series \(u_{n} = a + (n - 1)d\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[250, 440, 539, 470]]<|/det|>
\[S_{n} = \frac{1}{2} n(a + l) = \frac{1}{2} n\{2a + (n - 1)d\}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 494, 343, 512]]<|/det|>
Geometric series \(u_{n} = a r^{n - 1}\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[250, 515, 435, 580]]<|/det|>
\[S_{n} = \frac{a(1 - r^{n})}{1 - r} (r\neq 1)\] \[S_{\infty} = \frac{a}{1 - r} (|r|< 1)\]  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 617, 599, 636]]<|/det|>
## 2. TRIGONOMETRY  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 650, 161, 668]]<|/det|>
Identities  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[421, 678, 589, 730]]<|/det|>
\[\sin^{2}A + \cos^{2}A = 1\] \[\sec^{2}A = 1 + \tan^{2}A\] \[\csc \mathrm{e}^{2}A = 1 + \cot^{2}A\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 772, 247, 791]]<|/det|>
Formulae for \(\Delta ABC\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 798, 599, 833]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{a}{\sin A} = \frac{b}{\sin B} = \frac{c}{\sin C}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 834, 599, 855]]<|/det|>
\[a^{2} = b^{2} + c^{2} - 2bc\cos A\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 860, 561, 890]]<|/det|>
\[\Delta = \frac{1}{2} bc\sin A\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 77, 99, 96]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 75, 655, 98]]<|/det|>
On the axes, sketch the graph of \(y = 4 \sin 3x - 2\) for \(-\frac{\pi}{3} \leqslant x \leqslant \frac{\pi}{3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 76, 920, 96]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 104, 871, 465]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 77, 97, 97]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 77, 146, 97]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 75, 920, 116]]<|/det|>
Show that \(2x^{2} + x - 15\) can be written in the form \(2\big(x + a\big)^{2} + b\) , where \(a\) and \(b\) are exact constants to be found.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 92, 920, 112]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 280, 146, 299]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 278, 848, 301]]<|/det|>
Hence write down the coordinates of the stationary point on the curve \(y = 2x^{2} + x - 15\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 280, 920, 299]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 357, 144, 376]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 355, 920, 395]]<|/det|>
On the axes, sketch the graph of \(y = \left|2x^{2} + x - 15\right|\), stating the coordinates of the points where the graph meets the coordinate axes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 375, 920, 393]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[141, 406, 836, 759]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 846, 146, 864]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 842, 920, 881]]<|/det|>
Write down the value of the constant \(k\) for which the equation \(\left|2x^{2} + x - 15\right| = k\) has 3 distinct solutions.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 861, 920, 880]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 504, 89]]<|/det|>
Solve the following simultaneous equations.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[437, 101, 561, 121]]<|/det|>
\[3y - 2x + 2 = 0\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[504, 128, 561, 154]]<|/det|>
\[xy = \frac{1}{2}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 131, 920, 151]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 520, 146, 539]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 520, 777, 540]]<|/det|>
Solve the equation \(\log_3 x + 3 = 10 \log_3 3\), giving your answers as powers of 3.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 520, 920, 539]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 94, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 75, 920, 112]]<|/det|>
The polynomial \(\mathrm{p}(x)\) is such that \(\mathrm{p}(x) = ax^{3} + 13x^{2} + bx + c\) , where \(a, b\) and \(c\) are integers. It is given that \(\mathrm{p}'(0) = - 9\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 121, 144, 140]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 121, 304, 140]]<|/det|>
Show that \(b = - 9\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 121, 920, 140]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 230, 920, 266]]<|/det|>
It is also given that \(3x + 2\) is a factor of \(\mathrm{p}(x)\) and that when \(\mathrm{p}(x)\) is divided by \(x + 1\) the remainder is 6.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 277, 144, 295]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 277, 364, 295]]<|/det|>
Find the values of \(a\) and \(c\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 277, 920, 295]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 673, 144, 692]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 673, 601, 692]]<|/det|>
Find the quadratic \(\mathrm{q}(x)\) such that \(\mathrm{p}(x) = (3x + 2)\times \mathrm{q}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 673, 920, 692]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 828, 146, 846]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 828, 710, 846]]<|/det|>
Hence find \(\mathrm{p}(x)\) as a product of linear factors with integer coefficients.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 828, 920, 846]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 78, 94, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 920, 114]]<|/det|>
A geometric progression is such that the fifteenth term is equal to \(\frac{1}{8}\) of the twelfth term. The sum to infinity is 5.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 125, 144, 144]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 125, 479, 144]]<|/det|>
Find the first term and the common ratio.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 125, 920, 144]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 514, 146, 532]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 514, 920, 548]]<|/det|>
Find the least number of terms needed for the sum of the geometric progression to be greater than 4.999.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 528, 920, 547]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 94, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 561, 96]]<|/det|>
A function \(\mathrm{f}(x)\) is such that \(\mathrm{f}(x) = \mathrm{e}^{3x} - 4\) , for \(x \in \mathbb{R}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 106, 146, 125]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 106, 311, 126]]<|/det|>
Find the range of f.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 107, 920, 126]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 183, 146, 202]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 183, 395, 202]]<|/det|>
Find an expression for \(\mathrm{f}^{-1}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 184, 920, 203]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 415, 144, 435]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 415, 920, 452]]<|/det|>
On the axes, sketch the graphs of \(y = \mathrm{f}(x)\) and \(y = \mathrm{f}^{-1}(x)\) stating the exact values of the intercepts with the coordinate axes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 432, 920, 451]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[141, 465, 838, 816]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 437, 89]]<|/det|>
In this question all lengths are in metres.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[222, 101, 777, 266]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 282, 920, 333]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a circle, centre \(O\), radius 7. The points \(A\) and \(B\) lie on the circumference of the circle. The line \(BC\) is a tangent to the circle at the point \(B\) such that the length of \(BC\) is 24. The length of the minor arc \(AB\) is 12.25.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 345, 144, 364]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 345, 613, 364]]<|/det|>
Find the obtuse angle \(AOB\), giving your answer in radians.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 345, 920, 364]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 438, 146, 457]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 438, 470, 457]]<|/det|>
Find the perimeter of the shaded region.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 439, 920, 457]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 428, 88]]<|/det|> Find the area of the shaded region. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 71, 920, 88]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 317, 94, 336]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 317, 665, 338]]<|/det|> A 6-character password is to be formed from the following characters. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[227, 346, 495, 432]]<|/det|>
LettersABCD
Numbers1234
Symbols*#$£
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 443, 583, 462]]<|/det|> No character may be used more than once in any password. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 473, 144, 492]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 473, 180, 492]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 473, 751, 492]]<|/det|> Find the number of different 6-character passwords that can be formed. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 473, 920, 492]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 551, 181, 570]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 551, 685, 570]]<|/det|> How many of these 6-character passwords end with a symbol? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 551, 920, 570]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 628, 146, 647]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 628, 920, 662]]<|/det|> Find the number of different 6-character passwords that include all the symbols, but do not start or end with a symbol. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 643, 920, 662]]<|/det|> [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 104, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 922, 96]]<|/det|>
Solve the equation \(\sqrt{2} \cos (3x + 1.2) = 2 \sin (3x + 1.2)\), where \(x\) is in radians, for \(-1.5 \leqslant x \leqslant 1.5\). [5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 82, 104, 102]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 836, 109]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(\int_{1}^{a}\left(\frac{3}{3x + 2} -\frac{2}{2x + 1} -\frac{1}{x}\right)\mathrm{d}x = \ln \frac{1}{5},\) where \(a > 1\). Find the exact value of \(a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 84, 920, 103]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 87, 104, 108]]<|/det|>
<label>12</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 77, 460, 116]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(y = \frac{\left(3x^{2} - 2\right)^{\frac{2}{3}}}{x - 1},\) for \(x > 1.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 134, 144, 154]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 126, 760, 170]]<|/det|>
Write \(\frac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{dx}}\) in the form \(\frac{\left(3x^{2} - 2\right)^{-\frac{1}{3}}}{\left(x - 1\right)^{2}} (x^{2} + Ax + B)\), where \(A\) and \(B\) are integers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 135, 920, 155]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 588, 143, 606]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 586, 801, 609]]<|/det|>
Find the approximate increase in \(y\) as \(x\) increases from 2 to \(2 + p\), where \(p\) is small.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 586, 920, 606]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 73, 106, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>13</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
The points \(P\) and \(Q\) have coordinates \((5, - 12)\) and \((15, - 6)\) respectively. The point \(R\) lies on the line \(l\), the perpendicular bisector of the line \(PQ\). The \(x\)-coordinate of \(R\) is 7.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 146, 138]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 119, 368, 138]]<|/det|>
Find the \(y\)-coordinate of \(R\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 119, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 475, 146, 494]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 475, 920, 510]]<|/det|>
The point \(S\) lies on \(l\) such that its distance from \(PQ\) is 3 times the distance of \(R\) from \(PQ\). Find the coordinates of the two possible positions of \(S\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 491, 920, 510]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]
